prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Disk Snapshots
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A 1.3 mm (Band 6) continuum snapshot survey to measure dust masses in a sample of young, binary T Tauri stars and a matched control sample of single T Tauri stars. We aim for a uniform sensitivity of 0.1 mJy/beam for each target.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our main goal is continuum, so we target the maximum available aggregate bandwidth.
The windows are set to moderately averaged FDM mode in order to allow serendipitous detections of spectral lines.

Our experiment focuses on integrated disk masses compared between single stars and binaries. In order to best recover all of the flux and to maximize signal-to-noise, we propose to use the ALMA 12-m array in its most compact configuration (C36-1). This will allow us to probe spatial scales of ~200-1600 AU. For this, we expect most disks to be only moderately resolved.
We checked the literature on binary debris disks (similar but not identical) and there does not appear to be any evidence for circumbinary disks of size > 1000 AU. We therefore set this as the maximum expected scale for the experiment.

We want to obtain disk dust mass estimates by observing the 1.3mm continuum in a population of binary and single T Tauri stars. Consulting literature (pre-ALMA) surveys, we see that the distribution of disk mass fluxes in similar objects follows a falling luminosity function with about half of the targets detected by 10 mJy (see proposal figures drawn from Andrews & Williams ). We don't know the fluxes of the undetected systems and we don't know how much binary systems will be suppressed in dust mass, but if the distribution function can be extrapolated it seems clear that almost all systems will have fluxes >~ 1 mJy. We target 0.1 mJy/beam rms to detect such systems at S/N > 10. This also allows the flux to be distributed over some extended area in more massive systems (i.e., the disk can be bigger than our beam and we still detect it).
We input 10 mJy, about the median 1.3mm disk flux in the previous literature surveys, into the OT as a likely maximum for our targets.
Please note that the OT requires an estimate of the line flux when using a spectral setup, but that the lines are not our main science goal. We observe them as secondary science targets and to improve the archival value of the data.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Nearly half of all solar-type stars are in multiple systems, and roughly one in three are binaries. Since planet formation is a general phenomenon, intimately tied to the conditions in protoplanetary disks, it is thus important to understand differences in the properties of disks around single and binary stars. However, the simple experiment of comparing the mm-based disk masses around a matched set of binary and single stars has yet to be carried out. We propose to do so by carrying out a 1.3 mm continuum (Band 6) snapshot survey of 22 (12 binary, 10 single) T Tauri stars in the nearby (d ~ 140-160 pc) Sco-Oph star forming region. Our targets are young with similar distributions of spectral type between the binary and single subsamples, allowing for a fair comparison of their demographics. This very affordable experiment will help inform models of planet formation and provide important information to the active subfield of exoplanet multiplicity studies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Ohio State University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Ohio State University
